qas.question: What organization rated Comcast's customer service the worst in the country in 2004 and 2007?
Comcast's customer service was rated worse than what government organization?
When did the ACSI begin doing customer satisfaction surveys?
When Comcast's customer service rating fell 7%, what happened to its revenues?
What prime factor did the ACSI use to explain this anomaly?

answers.text: most cable companies have little competition at the local level

qas.question: Who listed the IRS as the company with the worst customer service rating?
What is the only industry to score above a 60?
How much did customer satisfaction increase by?
What company was given the worst customer satisfaction rating in 2001?
What has happened to the revenue of the Internal Revenue Service?

context: In 2004 and 2007, the <a0_0><b5_0>American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI)<b5_0/><a0_0/> survey found that <b8_0>Comcast<b8_0/> had the worst customer satisfaction rating of any company or government agency in the country, including <a1_0>the Internal Revenue Service<a1_0/>. The ACSI indicates that almost half of all cable customers (regardless of company) have registered complaints, and that <b6_0>cable<b6_0/> is the only industry to score below 60 in the ACSI. Comcast's Customer Service Rating by the ACSI surveys indicate that the company's customer service has not improved since the surveys began in <a2_0>2001<a2_0/>. Analysis of the surveys states that "Comcast is one of the lowest scoring companies in ACSI. As its customer satisfaction eroded by <b7_0>7%<b7_0/> over the past year, revenue <a3_0><b9_0>increased by 12%<b9_0/><a3_0/>." The ACSI analysis also addresses this contradiction, stating that "Such pricing power usually comes with some level of monopoly protection and <a4_0>most cable companies have little competition at the local level<a4_0/>. This also means that a cable company can do well financially even though its customers are not particularly satisfied."
